strategic_profile.executive_summary: A large public university known for its vibrant campus life, strong athletic programs, and increasing academic rigor. Strong regional player with growing national recognition, particularly in business and engineering.
strategic_profile.market_position: Strong regional player with growing national recognition, particularly in business and engineering.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Holistic review with an emphasis on academic achievement, extracurricular involvement, and leadership potential. Seeks to build a diverse and engaged student body.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Potential for further climb in national rankings.
Needs to balance rapid growth with maintaining student experience.
Strong alumni network is a major asset.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Very active, Greek-life dominant, strong sense of community and tradition.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Campus is walkable, but a car is useful for off-campus amenities. Bus system available.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Significant growth in research funding and output, particularly in interdisciplinary fields like cybersecurity and advanced materials.

current_status.test_policy_details: The University of Alabama is test-optional for admissions through the Fall 2026 semester. Standardized ACT or SAT scores are not required for the admission review, but can be submitted for merit scholarship consideration. The University of Alabama System announced on December 18, 2025, that it will reinstate the requirement for standardized test scores for applicants beginning in August 2026 (for Fall 2027 entry and beyond).

longitudinal_trends.notes: Data for Fall 2025 (Class of 2029) is estimated based on a reported decrease in applicants and an acceptance rate for the 'most recent admission cycle (2025)'. Final enrollment figures are not yet available.
The University started test-optional admissions with the Fall 2021 incoming class and has extended this through Fall 2024.
Data sourced from the University of Alabama's Common Data Set 2023-2024.
Data sourced from the University of Alabama's Common Data Set 2022-2023.
The University started test-optional admissions with the Fall 2021 incoming class. Data sourced from the University of Alabama's Common Data Set 2021-2022.

gpa.notes: For Fall 2025, the middle 50% GPA for admitted students (combining AL Resident and Non-Resident data where applicable) falls within these ranges. The University of Alabama utilizes a holistic admissions process, considering various factors beyond GPA, including high school course rigor (e.g., AP/IB classes), extracurricular activities, leadership experience, essays, and standardized test scores (if submitted). While an unweighted average GPA of admitted students is frequently cited around 3.86-3.87, an explicit average weighted GPA is not consistently provided in available public data. Approximately 91% of admitted students for 2022 had high school GPAs of 3.0 or above.

testing.policy_note: UA will superscore for admission purposes. Standardized test scores are not required for students applying through the Fall 2026 Semester but will be required for students applying for the Fall 2027 and 2028 academic years. For the academic year 2025, 43% of enrolled students submitted ACT scores and 15% submitted SAT scores.

men.note: Data for Fall 2010 admissions (Common Data Set 2010-2011).

women.note: Data for Fall 2010 admissions (Common Data Set 2010-2011).

colleges.name: J. Frank Barefield Jr. College of Arts and Sciences

majors.name: Data Science
majors.special_requirements: This forward-looking program combines machine learning, AI and ethical data analysis.
majors.notes: New major for 2025. Prepares students for roles such as data analyst, data architect/engineer, data scientist, machine learning engineer, and operations research analyst. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, New University of Alabama Majors and Minors for 2025

colleges.housing_profile: General freshman housing (suite or traditional style with standard amenities). Specific LLCs include Blount Hall for Blount Scholars (double occupancy, shared bath, seminar rooms, community kitchen) and John England Jr. Hall for Parker-Adams LLC (double occupancy, private bath). McCollough Institute for Pre-Medical Scholars are in Ridgecrest South (2- or 4-bedroom suites, private baths, living room, kitchenette).
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, diverse interests, liberal arts focused. Blount Scholars are seeking interdisciplinary learning; Parker-Adams students desire a supportive community; Pre-Medical Scholars are academically strong and service-oriented.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic curiosity and interest in a broad range of subjects. Consider LLCs for specialized academic support, community, and pre-professional preparation.

colleges.name: Capstone College of Nursing

majors.name: Nursing
prerequisite_courses: Human Anatomy & Physiology I with Lab
Human Anatomy & Physiology II with Lab
Intro to Organic Chemistry with Lab
weeder_courses: Human Anatomy & Physiology I with Lab
Human Anatomy & Physiology II with Lab
Intro to Organic Chemistry with Lab
majors.special_requirements: Students are admitted to the lower division of the Capstone College of Nursing by meeting University of Alabama admission requirements and declaring nursing as their major. Promotion to the upper division (professional component of the program) is competitive and occurs after the sophomore year. For promotion to the upper division, a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA on all required lower division courses and science courses is required. A departmental interview is required for transfer and second-degree students. All lower division courses must be completed with a grade of C- or higher.
majors.admissions_pathway: Direct Admit to Lower Division, Competitive Admission to Upper Division

core_courses: NUR 302 Child and Family Health Nursing
NUR 402 Leadership and Management in Nursing

majors.notes: The BSN program consists of lower division core curriculum courses and upper division nursing courses. The upper division consists of five semesters of nursing courses, including theory and clinical lab components. Graduates have an NCLEX-RN pass rate of around 92%. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, AllNurses

colleges.housing_profile: Students generally reside in standard freshman housing options, which include modern suite-style dorms (e.g., Presidential Village) or traditional halls. Off-campus options are also popular among nursing students seeking quiet study environments.
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate, dedicated, resilient, and driven to provide high-quality healthcare and make a difference in patient's lives, possessing strong critical thinking and communication skills.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Recommended for students committed to a challenging healthcare career, who are empathetic and possess strong academic discipline.

colleges.name: College of Communication and Information Sciences

majors.name: Advertising
majors.special_requirements: Minimum of 120 credit hours for graduation. Overall and UA GPA of 2.0 or higher, and a 2.0 or higher GPA in the major and minor. At least 12 hours at 300–400 level and at least 3 hours of Writing credit.
majors.notes: One of six undergraduate majors offered by the College of Communication and Information Sciences. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026.

majors.name: Communication Studies
majors.special_requirements: Minimum of 120 credit hours for graduation. Overall and UA GPA of 2.0 or higher, and a 2.0 or higher GPA in the major and minor. At least 12 hours at 300–400 level and at least 3 hours of Writing credit.
majors.notes: An Accelerated Master's Program (AMP) in Communication Studies allows eligible students to earn both BA and MA in five years. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, UA Online

colleges.housing_profile: John England Jr. Hall houses the Capstone Communication Living-Learning Community, offering double-occupancy rooms with private bathrooms and community spaces.
colleges.student_archetype: Aspiring professionals in media, communication, and information fields, who enjoy collaborative learning and networking.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Recommended for students passionate about communication and media, seeking an immersive, career-focused living and learning experience.

colleges.name: College of Education

majors.name: Kinesiology (Exercise Science Concentration)
majors.special_requirements: The concentration in Exercise Science does not lead to teacher certification.
majors.notes: Students in this program plan to enter into fields of exercise physiology, personal training, coaching, athletic coordination, sports nutrition, occupational therapy, or physical therapy. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026.

majors.name: Elementary Education
majors.special_requirements: Leads to Early Childhood (P-3) and Elementary Education (K-6th grade) certification. Teacher education programs lead to licensure in the state of Alabama.
majors.notes: Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, College of Education

colleges.housing_profile: Students typically reside in general freshman housing options, including traditional dorms like Burke or Paty, and suite-style dorms like Presidential Village, offering standard amenities.
colleges.student_archetype: Dedicated to teaching and educational leadership, patient, empathetic, and committed to making a positive impact on students and communities.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for individuals passionate about shaping future generations and contributing to educational development. Open to all general freshman housing options.

colleges.name: College of Human Environmental Sciences

majors.name: Human Environmental Sciences
majors.special_requirements: An approved program of study prior to the completion of 100 hours. Minimum of 120 earned semester credit hours, including all University Core Curriculum requirements and a minimum of 30 hours of coursework in disciplines offered by the College of Human Environmental Sciences, including HES 310 Improving Lives: Professionalism and Multidisciplinary Collaboration and HES 100 Freshman Compass Human Environmental Sciences (for on-campus freshmen) or HES 103 Distance Compass HES (for online students). 12 hours of 300-400 level courses, including HES 485 and HES 490. A 2.0 or higher GPA for all college-level courses, UA courses, and major courses.

core_courses: HES 100 Freshman Compass Human Environmental Sciences (for on-campus freshmen) OR HES 103 Distance Compass HES (for online students)
HES 310 Improving Lives: Professionalism and Multidisciplinary Collaboration
HES 485 Human Environmental Sciences Senior Seminar
electives: ADD 200 Introduction to Addiction and Recovery
CTD 200 Introduction to Clothing, Textiles and Design
ECY 200 Introduction to Early Childhood Education
HDFS 200 Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
HNHM 200 Introduction to Human Nutrition and Hospitality Management

majors.notes: This major allows students to develop an innovative program of study focusing on disciplines like addiction and recovery, athletic training, clothing and textiles, consumer sciences, early childhood education, human development and family studies, human nutrition, hospitality management, interior design, public health, and sport management. The program is available online. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, College of Human Environmental Sciences

colleges.housing_profile: Students typically reside in general freshman housing options, which include suite-style dorms (e.g., Lakeside) and traditional dorms (e.g., Burke), offering furnished rooms, internet, and laundry facilities.
colleges.student_archetype: Individuals focused on improving quality of life, with interests in areas such as fashion, nutrition, hospitality, human development, and consumer sciences.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Best for those who want to blend scientific understanding with practical application to enhance human well-being and societal health.

colleges.name: Culverhouse College of Business

majors.name: Management Information Systems
majors.special_requirements: All Management Information Systems major program courses must be completed in residence.
majors.notes: Management Information Systems and Services graduates have a median starting salary of $67,700. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, CollegeSimply.

majors.name: Accounting
majors.special_requirements: All major program courses required by the Culverhouse School of Accountancy must be completed in residence.
majors.notes: The Culverhouse School of Accountancy offers a broad range of course specializations focusing on public accounting, management accounting, auditing, taxation, and nonprofit accounting. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, Culverhouse College of Business

majors.name: Finance
majors.special_requirements: Undergraduate students seeking a degree in finance must select an additional major or specialization.
majors.notes: Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, Culverhouse College of Business

majors.name: Marketing
majors.notes: Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, Culverhouse College of Business

majors.name: General Business
majors.special_requirements: A minimum grade of C- is required in each course.

core_courses: AC 351 Managerial Accounting Decisions OR AC 352 Corporate Financial Reporting OR AC 361 Cost Analysis for Planning and Control

majors.notes: This degree program is offered 100% online. Students will major in General Business and can begin coursework any semester. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026.

colleges.housing_profile: Primarily general freshman housing (e.g., Presidential Village, Lakeside - modern suite-style dorms with shared living areas and kitchenettes). The Crimson Innovator Hub LLC in Blount Hall (double occupancy, shared bath, seminar rooms, community kitchen) caters to entrepreneurial students.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious, career-focused, often entrepreneurial, with strong academic records and a drive for success in business.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students focused on a business career, valuing networking and practical experience. Consider the Crimson Innovator Hub if interested in entrepreneurship.

colleges.name: Lee J. Styslinger Jr. College of Engineering

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.special_requirements: A maximum of 12 hours can be transferred at the 200/300/400 level for Computer Science degree programs. Senior design course(s) must be taken at UA.
majors.notes: The B.S. in Cyber Security is offered through the Computer Science department. Engineering students are limited to three attempts of any math, science, or engineering course required for the degree. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, Lee J. Styslinger Jr. College of Engineering

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Engineering students are limited to three attempts of any math, science, or engineering course that is required for the degree.
majors.notes: Electrical, Electronics and Communications Engineering graduates have a median starting salary of $71,600. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, CollegeSimply, Research.com

majors.name: Chemical Engineering
majors.notes: Chemical Engineering graduates have a median starting salary of $64,700. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, CollegeSimply.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.notes: Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.notes: Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026.

colleges.housing_profile: Bryant Hall is designated for male freshman engineering students (2 or 4-bedroom suites with living rooms, kitchenettes, and private bathrooms). Other engineering students may reside in general freshman housing (e.g., Presidential Village, Lakeside - modern suite-style).
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers, logical thinkers, detail-oriented, with a strong aptitude for STEM subjects and an interest in practical application.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students with strong STEM backgrounds. Male engineering students should consider Bryant Hall for a specialized community.

colleges.name: School of Social Work

majors.name: Social Work
majors.special_requirements: Students must formally apply to the BSSW Professional program. Minimum grades of C in all required social work courses and two social work electives. Minimum grades of C in all other courses required in the major. Students under any catalog before the 2023-2024 Undergraduate Catalog are eligible to take an optional writing assessment to test out of SW 310, Professional Writing Seminar.

core_courses: SW 200 Introduction to Social Work Practice
SW 300 Social Work with Individuals and Families
SW 350 Human Behavior and the Social Environment
SW 400 Social Welfare Policy and Services
SW 450 Social Work with Groups, Communities, and Organizations
SW 490 Social Work Field Practicum I
SW 491 Social Work Field Practicum II
electives: SW 320 Social Work in Health Care
SW 340 Social Work with Older Adults

majors.notes: Prepares graduates for beginning-level professional social work practice. Requires a 2.25 cumulative GPA and 2.5 GPA in social work courses for admission to the major. Data source: University of Alabama Catalog 2025-2026, School of Social Work

colleges.housing_profile: Undergraduate social work students can participate in the Parker-Adams LLC in John England Jr. Hall. Otherwise, they reside in general freshman housing options. Graduate students typically seek off-campus housing.
colleges.student_archetype: Empathetic, service-oriented, advocates for social justice, and committed to improving societal well-being through community engagement and direct practice.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Best for individuals passionate about helping vulnerable populations and working towards positive community change. Consider the Parker-Adams LLC for a supportive community.

honors_college_program_info.housing_profile: Dedicated housing in Ridgecrest West and Ridgecrest South (home to Honors Connections LLC), and Blount Hall (shared with Blount Scholars). These are modern suite-style dorms with study rooms, community kitchens, and social spaces.
honors_college_program_info.student_archetype: High-achieving, intellectually curious, motivated, valuing academic rigor, research, leadership, and a close-knit community of like-minded peers.
honors_college_program_info.strategic_fit_advice: Highly recommended for top academic students seeking an enriched collegiate experience, advanced learning opportunities, and strong peer and faculty connections through specialized programs and housing.

application_deadlines.plan_type: Early Action (Priority Admission & Automatic Merit Scholarship)
application_deadlines.notes: Priority deadline for admission and automatic merit scholarship consideration for Summer or Fall 2026 terms.

Priority deadline for general admissions and final deadline for competitive scholarships. Applications submitted after this date will be considered on a space-available basis. Also a priority deadline for automatic merit scholarships.
The University of Alabama has a rolling admissions policy; applications are considered on a space-available basis after priority deadlines.

supplemental_requirements.details: Two short response essays (up to 150 words each) are required for general admission and scholarship consideration. Applicants select from prompts related to elected/appointed leadership positions, significant academic achievements/honors/awards, volunteer experience, extracurricular activities, and paid positions. These are considered holistically.

A 400-word essay is required, based on two of the following topics: how UA Early College will help achieve college goals, skills and abilities for college study, or academic achievements and preparation for college study.

A 'Self-Statement' comprising two essay prompts (400-600 words total). Prompt 1 requires demonstrating readiness for a self-designed and self-directed course of study by responding to one of several options (e.g., advocating for self, exhibiting resilience, adapting to fluid situations). Prompt 2 requires describing a proposed plan of study, combining subject areas and mentioning specific departments, courses, or independent study ideas.

One letter of recommendation from someone who can describe the applicant's likelihood of success in a program emphasizing academic independence, creativity, and responsibility (teachers and educational counselors are recommended).

Prepare three memorized solo selections; one must be in a foreign language for all degree programs (Vocal Performance, Music Education, Music Minors, BA programs). Music Therapy students do not audition for voice faculty. BA students and minors may substitute two musical theatre selections if the third is a classical solo in a foreign language. Secondary students/non-majors interested in MUA 134 or MUA 234 contact Dr. Susan Williams for an interview and 'Happy Birthday' audition.
Prepare at least three memorized works of contrasting style exhibiting musical and technical proficiency (e.g., Bach Inventions, Kuhlau Sonatinas level). Sight-reading is also required.

The audition must include works of contrasting style that exhibit lyrical and technical difficulty appropriate to college music study. Repertoire may include solos, études, and/or orchestral excerpts. Audition dates are for Fall 2026 admission.

Requirements include two classical pieces of varying styles (études are acceptable with faculty consultation), two jazz tunes (e.g., a blues and a jazz standard, performed with melody, improvisation, and comping if applicable), basic jazz improvisation, sight-reading, and major/minor scales (minimum 2 octaves, ascending/descending to the 9th, with arpeggiation).
All students must pass an audition to declare a general music major. Auditions typically occur between January and March prior to fall enrollment.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: Pre-screening recordings required to obtain an audition. Auditions live on campus or Zoom: January 31, 2026; February 14, 2026 (Zoom); February 15, 2026; March 7, 2026
supplemental_requirements.details: Pre-screening recordings (3 video selections, including at least one opera aria for opera assistantships) are required. The full audition program (combining pre-screening and live/Zoom) should include five or six varied selections for MM and a 20-25 minute recital program for DMA. Auditions demonstrate understanding of various vocal styles, diction, and foreign languages. No GRE scores are required.

A pre-screening application with three varied selections (at least one in English) must be submitted by December 1st. Audition with a University ensemble, conducting two major works in contrasting styles. Ear training and sight-singing proficiency are also assessed.

Prospective master's students prepare a program of no less than 30 minutes of memorized music representing at least three contrasting styles. Prospective doctoral students prepare a program of no less than 60 minutes of memorized music representing at least three contrasting styles. A complete sonata is strongly encouraged for both.
In lieu of an instrumental audition, students meet with theory faculty for an interview and submit a portfolio for review.
Generally, three works of contrasting style that exhibit musical and technical difficulty appropriate to college music study. Repertoire may include solos, études, and/or orchestral excerpts.

Auditions for Fall 2025/Spring 2026 placement take place on August 18-19, 2025. Specific times are given for trombones, trumpets, saxophones, and rhythm section instruments. Information and excerpts are available on the Jazz Studies website.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Music (Ensembles: Wind Ensemble, Symphonic Band, Concert Band)
supplemental_requirements.details: Auditions for Fall 2025 placement take place on August 18-19, 2025. Specific times are given for trumpet, horn, trombone, euphonium, tuba, percussion, flute, bassoon, oboe, clarinet, and saxophone. Audition materials are provided in a shared online folder.
Audition information is available for Spring 2026.
Information for Spring 2026 choral auditions/hearings is available.

holistic_review_factors.specific_differentiators: The University of Alabama uses a holistic review process for freshman admission, which includes both academic and non-academic criteria. The university is test-optional through the Fall 2026 Semester, meaning standardized test scores are not required for admission consideration and students will not be penalized for not submitting them. While general admission interviews are not considered, interviews are part of the selection process for certain competitive first-generation scholarships and the Honors College (especially for test-optional applicants). The university offers robust support and scholarship programs specifically for first-generation students, and alumni/ae relation is a considered factor for admission and specific scholarships.

essay_prompts.prompt: Include any elected or appointed leadership position you held in the last three years. List the name of the organization or group for which you held the leadership role and include your elected or appointed title/position. Include the duration of your position/title and a list of your accomplishments and responsibilities in the position.
essay_prompts.note: This is one of five options in the 'Select-A-Prompt Short Response' section, where students choose which information to provide. The section itself is required, but students select the content. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. Each essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: What specific challenge did you face in this leadership role, and how did you overcome it?
How did your actions or decisions impact the group or organization you led?
What new skill or perspective did you gain from this leadership experience?
Can you describe a moment when you had to motivate others, and what was the outcome?
How did this leadership position align with or challenge your personal values?

essay_prompts.prompt: List your significant academic achievements/honors/awards over the last three years. Indicate the appropriate year beside each honor.
essay_prompts.note: This is one of five options in the 'Select-A-Prompt Short Response' section, where students choose which information to provide. The section itself is required, but students select the content. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. Each essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: Beyond the award itself, what specific effort or dedication led to this achievement?
How has this academic honor influenced your approach to learning or your future academic goals?
Was there a particular class, project, or mentor that inspired this achievement?
What was the most challenging aspect of earning this recognition?
How do these achievements reflect your intellectual curiosity or passion for a specific subject?

essay_prompts.prompt: For each event or organization you volunteered with in the last three years, list the name of the event/organization, the duration and total hours you volunteered, and what your responsibilities or accomplishments were.
essay_prompts.note: This is one of five options in the 'Select-A-Prompt Short Response' section, where students choose which information to provide. The section itself is required, but students select the content. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. Each essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: What specific need or issue did your volunteer work address in the community?
Describe a memorable interaction or experience you had while volunteering and what you learned from it.
How did your contributions, no matter how small, make a difference?
Did this volunteer experience change your perspective on a particular social issue or group of people?
What skills did you develop or apply during your volunteer work?

essay_prompts.prompt: For each extracurricular activity you participated in over the last three years, list the name of the organization/team/group, the duration of your participation and your responsibilities or accomplishments as a member.
essay_prompts.note: This is one of five options in the 'Select-A-Prompt Short Response' section, where students choose which information to provide. The section itself is required, but students select the content. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. Each essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: What sparked your initial interest in this activity?
How did your involvement in this activity challenge you to grow or adapt?
Describe a specific project, performance, or event within this activity that you are particularly proud of.
How did you collaborate with others in this activity, and what was the outcome?
Beyond the listed accomplishments, what personal satisfaction or enjoyment did you derive from this activity?

essay_prompts.prompt: For each paid position you've held in the last three years, list the name of the employer, the title of your position, the duration and total hours you worked and a list of your responsibilities or accomplishments.
essay_prompts.note: This is one of five options in the 'Select-A-Prompt Short Response' section, where students choose which information to provide. The section itself is required, but students select the content. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. Each essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: What was the most challenging aspect of this job, and how did you handle it?
How did this work experience develop your sense of responsibility or independence?
Describe a specific situation where you had to solve a problem or make a decision on the job.
What skills did you learn or improve that you believe will be valuable in college?
How did this job contribute to your understanding of a particular industry or customer service?

essay_prompts.prompt: Explain any extraordinary circumstances or special needs.
essay_prompts.note: This is a separate 'Additional Info Short Response' section. It is considered for both admission and scholarship consideration. The essay box holds up to 150 words.
brainstorming_questions: How have these circumstances directly impacted your academic performance or extracurricular involvement?
What specific strategies or resources have you utilized to navigate these circumstances?
In what ways have these experiences shaped your resilience or perspective?
Is there anything specific you want the admissions committee to understand about your journey in light of these circumstances?
How have you advocated for yourself or others regarding these special needs or circumstances?

major_selection_tactics: Consider "Less Rigorous" Majors for General Admission (if undecided or profile is borderline for highly competitive programs).
Understand Direct vs. General Admit Programs (if applicable to undergraduate).
Research Major-Specific Requirements beyond General University Admission.
Engage with Academic Advisors and Recruiters Early.
college_ranking_tactics: Match academic interests and career aspirations with the specific colleges and their program offerings.
Evaluate the academic rigor and specific curriculum requirements of different colleges and their programs.
Seek guidance from academic advisors and career services to understand program fit and potential career pathways.
Investigate the specific majors, minors, and distinct degree options offered by each college within the university.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: The search results do not explicitly indicate that the University of Alabama's undergraduate application allows for the selection of a primary and a secondary/alternate major during the initial application process. Once an application is submitted, changes generally cannot be made to the declared major. Therefore, if a student is applying to a highly competitive major, the strategy would likely involve applying directly to their desired major and, if admission to that specific program is a concern, understanding the process for changing majors *after* admission. The University of Alabama demonstrates a flexible environment for students wishing to change their major once enrolled. Roughly half of undergraduate students change their majors at least once, with the first two years being the most common time for such changes to avoid delaying graduation. To declare or change a major within the College of Arts and Sciences, students can log into myBama and follow the 'change of curriculum' link. For changes to a major in a different college, such as the Culverhouse College of Business, students must contact the advising office of the intended college. Consulting with an academic advisor is strongly recommended before making a formal change, as they can help ensure the new major aligns with academic and career goals and assess its impact on the graduation timeline. Resources like the Career Center and a majors fair hosted each fall are available to help students explore different fields of study. While the university generally facilitates major changes, the ease of internal transfer can vary, particularly for competitive or 'impacted' majors. Discussions suggest that majors such as Business, Computer Science, Engineering, and Nursing can be among the hardest to switch into at many schools, and this often holds true at Alabama. The difficulty often stems from such majors being housed in separate, often more competitive, colleges with their own specific admission requirements for internal transfers. For instance, transferring into a major within the Culverhouse College of Business or the College of Engineering may involve specific GPA requirements or course prerequisites that need to be met. It is advisable for students interested in these fields to speak with advisors in the respective colleges to understand any specific internal transfer requirements or limitations.

financials.notes: The University of Alabama meets 57% of demonstrated financial need.

scholarships.name: Presidential Elite Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition for up to four years, first year of on-campus housing, $1,500 per year supplemental scholarship, and a $2,000 one-time allowance for research or international study.
scholarships.deadline: Automatic Consideration (Submit admission application and supporting documents by December 5 priority deadline for Summer/Fall entry)
scholarships.benefits: Covers tuition, housing for the first year, supplemental funds, and a research/international study allowance.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (Requires 4.0+ GPA and 36 ACT or 1600 SAT)

scholarships.name: National Merit Finalist Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition for up to five years, four years of on-campus housing, $4,000 per year supplemental scholarship, $2,000 one-time allowance for research or international study, and $500 per year book scholarship.
scholarships.deadline: December 5 priority deadline (list UA as college choice with National Merit Scholarship Corporation by May 1)
scholarships.benefits: Extensive coverage including tuition, housing, supplemental funds, research/study allowance, and book stipend.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration for National Merit Finalists who list UA as their college choice and submit application materials by deadline.

scholarships.name: UA Scholar (Out-of-State Automatic Merit Scholarship)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic Consideration (Submit admission application and all supporting documents by December 5 priority deadline for Summer/Fall entry)
scholarships.benefits: Significant yearly scholarship towards educational expenses for high-achieving out-of-state students.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (Requires 30-31 ACT or 1360-1410 SAT and 3.50+ GPA)

scholarships.name: Academic Elite Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition for four years, one year of on-campus housing, $9,000 per year supplemental scholarship (top scholar receives $9,000 first year, $19,000 years 2-4) and a $5,000 one-time allowance for research or international study (for top scholar).
scholarships.deadline: Requires acceptance into the Dr. Robert E. Witt University Fellows Program; refer to Witt University Fellows website for application details.
scholarships.benefits: Comprehensive scholarship for highly competitive students within the Witt University Fellows Program.
scholarships.application_method: Requires separate application and acceptance into the Dr. Robert E. Witt University Fellows Program.

scholarships.name: International Collegiate Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic Consideration (Submit admission application and supporting documents by December 5 for Summer/Fall 2026, November 3 for Spring 2026)
scholarships.benefits: Annual scholarship for international freshmen with strong academic records.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration (Requires 28 ACT or 1300-1320 SAT and 3.50+ GPA for international freshmen)

scholarships.name: UA Competitive Admissions Scholarship (International/Out-of-State)
scholarships.benefits: Awarded based on a holistic review of academic and non-academic factors.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration after submitting admission application and supporting documents by the deadline; additional application in Alabama Scholarship Award Manager (ASAM) may be required for other opportunities.

scholarships.name: Need-Based Grant
scholarships.deadline: FAFSA deadline (recommended to complete FAFSA by priority scholarship deadlines if applicable)
scholarships.benefits: Financial assistance for students demonstrating financial need.
scholarships.application_method: FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid)

ap_policy.general_rule: Score of 3 or higher can grant credit for many exams at the University of Alabama, with the amount of credit and specific course equivalency often determined by the score (ranging from 3 to 5).
exceptions: Credit for U.S. Government & Politics may be based on a portfolio review by the Department of Art and Art History, which appears to be an unusual stipulation.
Students may not receive credit for AP courses and placement credit for language study if they have already received credit for language study in high school.
ap_policy.usage: AP credits can satisfy some general education (core) requirements, and the student's college of enrollment has the authority to determine their applicability toward major and/or minor requirements. However, these credits are not considered University of Alabama institutional coursework and cannot fulfill the minimum of 50% of coursework required for a bachelor's degree at a four-year institution or the minimum of 25% of coursework required for the degree at the University of Alabama.

ib_policy.general_rule: Both HL and SL exams with a minimum score (typically 4 or 5, depending on the subject) grant credit

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Up to 60 semester hours may be transferred from a two-year college. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale is required for admission for all college-level work attempted. Additionally, a minimum of 50% of the coursework required to earn a bachelor's degree at UA must be earned at a bachelor's degree granting institution, and a minimum of 25% of the coursework required must be earned in residence at UA. Transferable courses with a grade of 'D-' or above may apply to degree requirements unless a grade of 'C-' is specifically required.

credit_policies.credit_philosophy: The University of Alabama offers academic credit for AP and IB examinations based on qualifying scores, with course equivalencies determined by subject and score. Transfer articulation agreements are available, allowing up to 60 semester hours from two-year colleges, provided a minimum 2.0 GPA is maintained. A significant portion of coursework must be completed at UA and a bachelor's degree-granting institution. AP and IB credits can satisfy general education requirements but are not considered institutional coursework towards residency requirements.

common_activities: Participating in school clubs (e.g., debate, robotics)
Engaging in artistic pursuits (music, art, drama)
red_flags: Poor academic performance in key subjects

outcomes.notes: Median earnings 10 years after enrollment and 6 years after enrollment are based on data from the U.S. Department of Education College Scorecard. A specific employment rate 2 years after graduation was not directly found from College Scorecard. The closest available data is 'Employed 1 Year After Graduation' at 96%.
